By 1987 the Quadripartite Agreement had proven itself and worked very well. The Soviet Union wasn't interested in provoking a crisis. There had been a pattern of interrelationships worked out between East Germany and West Berlin and the Western Germans. There were thousands of East Germans working in West Berlin on day projects, something that was unheard-of, unthought-of of ten or 15 years ago. In all of this, the allies were there as a safeguard, but were increasingly seen as not terribly relevant to the day-to-day operations in the city.

Ambassador Walters told me that he had been encouraged to believe that German unification would soon be a possibility as a consequence of the Soviet decision to pull out of Afghanistan. He had felt that this decision had immediate implications for Soviet policy in Eastern Europe. Once a decision had been taken to let one communist regime fail, it would be harder politically to prop up deteriorating communist regimes elsewhere. With the political and societal ferment brewing in 1989, serious challenges were bound to come soon to communist regimes in Eastern Europe. Putting down such challenges might require substantial application of Soviet military force and would probably be a dubious proposition anyway and it would go directly counter to Gorbachev’s policy of engagement and cooperation with the West and with what he was trying to achieve domestically.
Richard C. Barkley, Ambassador, German Democratic Republic, 1988-1990

There is in the East, air that is beginning to rise, there is reform potential, there are changes that will come. I felt my job was to look for those changes, but what I was looking for, to be honest, was change that would come from above, directed, guided, controlled and to some extent limited from above.
Glasnost was in full swing in the Soviet Union. Perestroika had started. There were limits to what Gorbachev could allow in reform in any part of Eastern Europe. Those limits were more restrictive in East Germany than anywhere else, because it was the most dangerous border in the world. It was the point where the two great forces, East and West, came together and where there was more to be risked and more to be lost by reckless policy. We assumed there would be a more cautious approach to reform in East Germany than anywhere else.
Richard C. Barkley, Ambassador, German Democratic Republic, 1988-1990

So on November ninth Shabovsky had a press conference. Shabovsky, an East German government official, was handed a piece of paper where he announces that in a very short time, there will be no travel restrictions on East German citizens between East and West Germany and East and West Berlin. The question was asked at that time, what does this mean. He said, "Well just what I said. Everybody will have a right to a visa. You can get that visa. There will be no exceptions and they can move back and forth." One of the journalists said, "Does that mean immediately?" He looked at the paper and said, "Yes, that means immediately."
The idea was of course to try to reassure dissident elements that nobody was going to be disadvantaged by being an East German citizen. You won't have to sneak out through the back door, for "we are strong and self confident."

How would the border guards handle this? We were informed they were told, "Don't shoot anybody and don't do anything, and if they push you, get out of the way." People simply said, "We want to go across, can we go?" They said, "OK, go ahead." Try to imagine a couple of checkpoint guys sitting there looking at huge mobs of people and wondering, “What are they going to do? I can't shoot; I have been told not to shoot. What do I do? " So of course all the cameras were there and they started to go through. And of course it was jubilation. People saying, "This is crazy. I can't believe this. I don't know what is happening here."
The vast majority of people went back to their jobs and their homes. They went back with a load of bananas or oranges or dishwasher soap. What you saw, however, was constant movement back and forth, but it wasn't only one way. It went in both directions. The day after on the 10th I drove with flags up on the limousine and demonstratively went through Checkpoint Charlie. We got a lot of cheers as we did that.

The symbolic value of the four victorious powers of World War II meeting to decide the fate of Germany was too much. West German Foreign Minister Genscher was furious.
The President had taken a leadership decision, in spite of what the British, French and Russians were saying and their concerns. President Bush focused on our commitment to West Germany, the democracy that had been built up and the fact that we’d had something like 15 million soldiers in West Germany. President Bush was severely criticized here at home the day the Berlin Wall fell for not getting up from his desk and, as he would say, “dance on the Wall.” He was self-confident and mature enough not to rub salt in Gorbachev's wounds. I happen to think he was exactly right. I understand that our public probably did not understand that and he was criticized for it. From their moccasins I can see why they felt he should be out popping champagne, this was wonderful; something the West had been waiting for forty years. But, he did the right thing at the right time. Gorbachev knew what President Bush was doing when the President did that. So, again, this cements the relationship that builds the trust. I think we all were lucky that these men on both sides were in those positions and those jobs at this time of enormous change. Gorbachev wrote himself out of a job and behaved incredibly the night that the Berlin Wall fell by basically telling the 375,000 Russian troops stationed in East Germany to stand down. He let it happen.
Baker's skill in my mind was in being able to anticipate and understand his adversary's political constraints. To understand how far the person sitting across the table you are negotiating with can go within his own political universe I think is very important. Baker was very good at that.

The name Two Plus Four was meant to show not only that it was different from the Four-Power conferences of the '40s and '50s, that there were two German states, two were before the four. Give me two weeks after unification is formally declared, to pack up and get out, and I will be gone. I have talked to Ambassador Walters and there would be a transition so the East Berlin staff can be employed in different things and helpful in the transition.” They said, “Sounds good.” So on that rather glorious day, October first, I was nowhere to be seen, and I watched it on television and realized that this is a major political event, one that I never thought I would see. I was extraordinarily delighted on one hand, but somewhat saddened by the loss of what I considered to be one of the best embassies I had ever served with. We started planning for merging the embassy in East Berlin with the mission in West Berlin and that happened very quickly. It went very fast because we didn’t want the Department to get it wrong. The Germans helped us; I’m looking at this from an admin point of view because they announced that when unification came there would no longer be missions in Berlin, all the foreign presences there would have to be accredited in a different way.
The Germans sought one kind of diplomatic presence—an embassy—in the capital of their reunited country, not the special missions to Berlin that belonged to the allied powers.
We went to the Department, we said, “Look, whether you like it or not the Germans say there is going to be one diplomatic presence in Berlin as of October 1, 1990, and we’ve got to figure out what it is.” Those are big secrets. When you’re talking about which Americans are going to stay in Berlin and which ones aren’t and who’s going to get what title in one section, you better believe we had to treat that as “top secret.”

How could we work on a long-term basis to undermine the Soviets’ hold over the area? It seemed to me that the only way to do that was through a system of deliberate contacts not only with the general population, but also with the regimes themselves in an attempt to change them over a period of time.

Gorbachev had proposed restructuring the Soviet economy, perestroika, and creating more openness in the society, glasnost. He would make this great reform and the socialist state would continue, reformed but it would last forever. Well, those two policies were opposed adamantly by Erich Honecker, who believed quite the opposite. If you began this process you would never maintain control, Honecker insisted and he defied Gorbachev. This defiance was done at great risk because East Germany was totally dependent on Gorbachev; in true sense it was a satellite of the Soviet Union. East Germany had no political legitimacy from its people; it was dependent on the military support of the Russians.

There would be no movement of Checkpoint Charlie until we have a time to make sure that it is not portrayed in a humiliating way for the Russians. It did turn out indeed that there was a large ceremony, in June in connection with one of the Two Plus Four meetings that took place in East Germany by Checkpoint Charlie. It was quite an interesting ceremony.

Our posture was that we had recognized East Germany to remain in step with West Germany, France, and Great Britain, who had already done so. In fact, we were the 111th country to recognize the German Democratic Republic. The US side had no smiles for photographers.
The East Germans and Soviets were delighted not only to have American representation in East Berlin, but to gain this in a person of John Sherman Cooper’s renown, as U.S. ambassador. Our presence and the American flag flapping from a window pole represented to them the completion of a legitimization process by the West.
Ambassador Cooper and I had argued that, despite the nature of the regime, the East Germans should be treated correctly and with a certain respect, consonant with proper diplomatic behavior on our part. This may seem a small point, but it was not. Communication in diplomacy takes many forms, and often consists of sending signals to the other side through actions, attitudes, and behavior sometimes no greater than a look of disapproval, a stiffening of one’s back or a smile.
East German officials were correct and courteous, but distant. Periodically, we would be treated to a lecture about the wonders and successes of communism, but this was an exception; our relations with East German officials were businesslike. Interested in promoting our presence, they tried to accommodate us and not offend us. They sought visible rapprochement as a propaganda objective, and understood that preaching ideology would not make a dent on us and might even have a negative impact.
George Ward, Deputy Chief of Mission, Bonn, 1989-1992

This photo captures the shoppers from East Berlin in 1989 that thronged into Berlin’s fashionable districts in search of items Western consumers long took for granted. U.S. diplomat, George Ward, Bonn, described how the effects of a market economy began to appear in East Germany.

The Berlin Chapter of the Assocation of the U.S. Army presented this plaque to the U.S. Minister in West Berlin in 1988. At that time, no one knew that he would be the last U.S. Minister to serve in the post.

The Soviets always wanted to say the Four Party Treaty was only referring to West Berlin; we wanted it to say it was referring to all of Berlin; so the final agreement brilliantly done by our ambassador, Ken Rush was that it simply said, Quadripartite Agreement. In many ways you can trace the unraveling of the Soviet system to that agreement, because it legalized a relationship and exchange of information between East Germany and West Germany.
There were all sorts of very interesting formulations about our duties because we were not going to say we were the embassy in East Germany, but that is in fact what we were. We wanted to avoid any recognition of East Berlin as the capital of East Germany so that formally we were not located there.

Home Depot-type stores started to proliferate. There were huge traffic jams around the latter as the East Germans began to buy materials to fix up their houses. The gray streets of Dresden, Leipzig and East Berlin began to bloom with color.
Once unification happened, the large cultural facilities of the mission in Berlin became available to everybody. One touching incident occurred—when the Wall opened, an East Berlin woman went back and returned library books to the American library in West Berlin that she had taken out before the Wall went up and had been unable to return. There were things like that. People remembered.

It was our presence in Berlin and our retaining our rights in Berlin, the French retained their rights, the British retained their rights; it was that on which the three were always completely agreed, the commanders of the allied garrisons. I think it’s due to this unity that the map of Europe reads as it does today. We had to maintain our rights in Berlin and to prevent the constant attempts of the Soviet Union to undermine our position, so that before we knew what was happening, we would find that we’d lost the game in Germany.

In the late 1960s, Brandon Grove, Jr., then serving as U.S. Liaison in West Berlin, described how he interacted frequently with then Berlin Mayor Willy Brandt. Brandt later became German Chancellor from 1969-1974.
The Consecration of a new East German building of the Evangelical Church in Eisenhuttenstadt, Germany.

There were many potential crises during the years 1965-1969, incidents at the Wall and checkpoints, on the Autobahn, or in areas of city administration. These were manageable, because we carefully assessed the nature of each provocation and the required Allied response, if any. A Soviet decision to escalate tensions was always possible. The Soviet government was celebrating its fiftieth anniversary, believing itself stable internally and a world power internationally. Its constant mischief-making in Berlin was intended to wear the West out, but failed to do so. The Russians historically backed down to the letter of wartime agreements when confronted by strong protests.

U.S. diplomat in East Berlin, Brandon Grove, Jr., empathized with East Germans who felt uncomfortable in the West’s more open, uninhibited society.

From left to right: East German First Secretary Erich Honecker, U.S. President Gerald Ford, and Austrian Chancellor Bruno Kreisky at the signing of the final documents of the European Security Conference in Helsinki.

It was always Brandt who took the initiative with East Germany, prodding the Bonn government to follow through. Brandt realized his “small steps” would become an important part of the Social Democratic Party’s platform in the next general election. The Western Allies scrambled in Berlin, Bonn and their capitals to keep pace with events. What we were hearing in Berlin from Brandt and his coterie was crucial to achieving an understanding of where Brandt was taking Germany.
Brandt was also talking with the Soviets directly, meeting occasionally in East Berlin with the Soviet Ambassador. Our Berlin mission was in the forefront of those who expected Brandt’s “small steps” gradually to lead to a wider range of topics for discussion between East and West. We were certain Brandt did not intend to keep contacts between East and West Berlin limited to technical levels. We saw that should he become Chancellor, the pace would accelerate. His motive in Ostpolitik was to achieve a more healthy and human relationship among Germans, even at the cost of accepting two German states. He was not a panderer or accommodator toward the East. Yet Brandt’s moves at times caused suspicion in Western capitals as to whether he might trade West Germany’s western orientation for reunification.

I came to understand this ambivalence. East Berliners, particularly those no longer young, were not sure they wanted to live like their relatives on the other side of the Wall. They coveted the affluence and were wary of the life-style. Many were concerned about the effects such freedoms would have on their own children.

We were very much in the Cold War. The East and West Germans did not discuss things together nor did the West Berliners and the East Berliners, and Western Allies did not talk to the East German authorities. The Soviets and East Germans, despite earlier diplomatic agreements, aspired to place the entire city of Berlin behind the Iron Curtain and remove the presence of the Western Allies.

The Protestant Church was the part of the society which in September 1989 began to coalesce as a political movement. When nothing happened anywhere else in society that summer of the crisis, it was the church that began to speak out ever more publicly and groups within the church began to form the first incipient political parties.
The first political demands in the reform process came from the crowds that were around the church in Leipzig that was holding every Monday large services that became political demonstrations and spilled out in the street. Those demonstrations in September and October were very important in putting enormous pressure upon the Honecker government, pressure that finally led to its fall.

Within a couple years after the Helsinki summit, in July 1975, we began to see reverberations in Eastern Europe of the positions on human rights and fundamental freedoms that those countries accepted. Courageous people in countries like Czechoslovakia, Vaclav Havel, for example, with the “Charter 77,” said to Gustav Husak, communist leader in Czechoslovakia, “Hey, you agreed at Helsinki, Mr. President, to respect these fundamental rights and freedoms, how about in our country?” It really started the ball rolling. We didn’t realize at the time what a tremendous ball we started rolling.

U.S. diplomat Winston Lord, Washington, D.C., pictured here, described how the Helsinki Accords of 1975 eventually helped support dissidents in Soviet bloc countries.

People would not accept casual invitations. I tried once and East German Protocol complained. I decided to ignore them, I went directly to the person I wanted, to see if he could come to dinner and I got a message back from Protocol, don’t do that because our people will still come to us, and unless you have a reason, a visiting dignitary, these invitations should not be extended. We do not accept casual invitations. That was that. The problems faced were solvable in increments, you could lay out a plan, you could work them, be frustrated, be annoyed, angered, offended by that regime, but you could deal with it.
We tried to dole contact with U.S. politicians out as rewards to the East Germans, without telling them, but an improvement in the human rights list might bring a visit that they could give some publicity to that made them look good. And we sort of let them know that there was a relationship and we worked every resource that we could find.
I stayed away from West Berlin, and I tried by example to encourage at least the substantive officers on the staff to stay away from West Berlin. When you come back from the West you have to go through that, momentary though it might be, depression, that hits every one going from West to East, and that jars your thinking and appreciation as well. So, I didn’t spend a lot of time in West Berlin.
Every so often I’d have a Big Mac attack and I’d run to the McDonald’s in West Berlin. I didn’t spend a lot of time there, but we went across to West Berlin for food. I for one believe it’s not fair to take it from the East Germans when we had access to abundance in the embassy stores.
U.S. Diplomacy: "...a system of deliberate contacts..." Jonathan Dean

Students appear here at a 1982 Peace Forum in Dresden, East Germany, displaying a universally recognized sign for peace. Ambassador Richard Barkley, East Berlin, described how the church movement affected the East German government.
End of U.S. occupation in West Berlin

Historians now generally agree that the Helsinki Accords definitely worked to the advantage of the West. The Helsinki Accords legitimized human rights as a point for discussion between East and West. This doesn’t mean that the Russians would simply roll over on human rights, human rights became a more legitimate item on which to make attacks on their record and to make appeals for improvement. Also, it gave a certain international cover and legitimacy to dissidents within these nations. This was one of the many situations which contributed to the unraveling of the Soviet Union. The Helsinki Accords turned out to be very much a factor serving the interests of the West.
The Hardening of Relations: West and East Germany
Robert Lochner, Director Radio in the American Sector (RIAS), Berlin, 1961-1968

Edward R. Murrow, gazing out in this professional portrait, was a legendary radio news broadcaster and director of the U.S. Information Agency. After observing the Wall being built in 1961, he made a telephone call to President John F. Kennedy, which U.S. diplomat Robert Lochner recalled.

We did know of course the importance for Gorbachev for his reforms to succeed. We also knew that there were a number of people in East Germany, particularly at the universities and the churches that were hoping that the examples of glasnost and perestroika would be picked up in East Germany. They were constantly told, "No this doesn't pertain to us. It doesn't have to happen here for we have already made the necessary reforms." Of course we didn't foresee what was going to happen.

Richard C. Barkley, German Affairs, Washington, D.C., 1969-1971

The cover of this booklet depicts U.S. President Nixon’s triumphant 1969 visit to West Berlin. It also illustrates U.S. diplomat Robert Barkley’s comment in this narrative about how German New Ostpolitik and U.S. détente overlapped. Barkley served in both in Bonn and East Berlin.

Ed Murrow’s arrival in West Berlin late in the evening of August 12, 1961 was taken as proof that the United States knew about the Wall going up. I would protest to my contacts that it was coincidence that Ed Murrow arrived on a routine inspection trip of the biggest overseas installation of the US Information Agency. They met that with snickering remarks such as, “C’mon now. Ed Murrow, the man who was known always to be where the action is, he arrives accidentally the night before the Wall? Don’t give us that.”
Ed said he would like to go over and have a look for himself. My colleagues and I took Ed in a State Department car to East Berlin. From Berlin we drove to a reception for a man of cabinet rank like Ed Murrow, who was Director of the U.S. Information Agency. At one stage Ed Murrow asked me to arrange calling President Kennedy. The security people took him upstairs for the call. In reports over the years since then I have heard that historians are agreed that that phone call from Ed Murrow was really the first one to alert President Kennedy to the full seriousness of the situation – a devastating impact on the West Berliners’ morale. I have also heard it said that in that phone call the idea was born that six days later Kennedy sent Vice President Johnson and more important to the Berliners, General Clay, the hero of the airlift, to Berlin. From my own participation I know that that was very effective in sort of stopping the erosion of morale among the West Berliners. Of course it was combined with the gesture of sending troops up from West Germany.
Hans N. Tuch, Director, Amerika Haus, United States Information Agency, West Germany, 1949-1952

In the late 1940s and onward, U.S. diplomat Hans N. “Tom” Tuch, portrayed in this photo, worked to instill a sense of democracy in West Germany through the America House programs that he described in this narrative.

There had always been a deeper level of emotional commitment between Social Democracy and Communism than many people would like to admit. It was a long time before the Social Democratic Party declared itself a non-Marxist party. So Willy Brandt, who came out of that entire era, always had some interest in trying to engage in the East. I think the reason that there was not as much anxiety over this was that the United States was at that time going through its own policy of détente with the Soviets. The key was the Berlin agreements. Of course in Berlin there could be no agreement without the Four Powers. The Germans had nothing to do with Berlin. It was still actually an occupied area. So we engaged in the Berlin agreements which took 90% of the time of the German Bureau while I was there. It was a fascinating time.
Brandon Grove, Jr., Deputy Chief of Mission, East Berlin, 1974-1976

The words reproduced in the image here are from the surveillance file on U.S. diplomat G. Jonathan Greenwald, East Berlin, compiled by the Stasi, or East German secret police. U.S. diplomat Brandon Grove, Jr., posted to East Berlin, reflected on living in East Berlin with Stasi presence everywhere.

After the end of the war, the U.S. authorities established a number of what became known as America Houses to serve as library, cultural and information centers in various cities in Germany. These cities had for the most part been destroyed. These America Houses became the community centers for these cities. They helped these communities reestablish a cultural infrastructure. They had a library, music programs, lecture programs, children’s programs, English teaching facilities. They served as a very broad gauge community center. In my view they did a lot to help the Germans emotionally and culturally reestablish their society. For instance, one of the things which I think was significant was that America House libraries were open shelf libraries where people could go into the library and pick out their own book, check it out, read it there, or take it home. They were the first such libraries that the Germans had even seen.

What we did was closely monitored by the East Germans. If we wanted to have sensitive conversations, we walked the streets. At the embassy, we needed to take down one of the walls in our office so we could install a “bubble,” a secure and shielded enclosure the size of a small conference room. We recommended that people on our staff who wanted to discuss sensitive personal matters use this room to protect their privacy. We would point to the ceiling if someone was about to discuss things that should not be overheard, sign language universally understood behind the Iron Curtain.

U.S. Ambassador David Bolen (right) greets East German Chairman of the Council of State Erich Honecker upon Bolen’s presenting his credentials in 1977. U.S. diplomat Jonathan Dean in Bonn reflected on U.S. reservations about conducting diplomacy in this hard-line communist country.

There was a fear in Washington, not only of Sovietphobes, that East Germany would end up with its status increased. Indeed, that was exactly what did happen. East Germany in practice became associated with the four wartime Allies and the Federal Republic of Germany in the administration of Berlin. That was the practical outcome of these Berlin negotiations. And as part of the whole complex, the Federal Republic recognized East Germany as an independent state. They assumed diplomatic relations with one another and both German nations entered the United Nations as independent states.
Of course, the basic importance of the Ostpolitik and all of these agreements, coming to the final outcome and the conclusion, was that the West Germans convinced the East German officials that, if there was some kind of political settlement, the East Germans were not going to be taken out and executed by the victors. That eliminated probably the most basic reason for resisting the later unification.

Edward Alexander, Public Affairs Officer, United States Information Agency, Berlin, 1976-1979

The colorful exhibition The Splendors of Dresden opened the new East Wing of Washington, DC’s National Gallery of Art in 1978. U.S. diplomat Edward Alexander, East Berlin, explained its importance as he described his work in public diplomacy.

I was at the Foreign Ministry and I asked permission to go the university to meet the Dean and to present him with a thousand books that the United States Information Agency had sent me for their library. And he said, “I’m sorry but that’s just not possible.”
I said, “Why isn’t it possible?”
He said, “Well, the university is off limits, you just can’t go there. Send the books here and I’ll see what I can do.”
I said, “the books were not meant for the Foreign Ministry, they were meant for the university.”
So this went back and forth. I finally said, “I spent four years in Hungary and I never had this kind of difficulty in Hungary.”
He says, “We know you and we know what you did in Hungary. The German Democratic Republic is not Hungary.” This was very early in my time there. But it slowly did melt little by little. However, with a lot of pleading and a lot of understanding, I was able to get some good things done.
We began negotiating for the Dresden art exhibit. It would coincide with the opening of the East Wing of the National Gallery. The East Germans wanted that so badly that they conceded certain things to me. I was able to put on a number of things--one, a film festival in Leipzig a thousand people attended. I wrote a speech for Ambassador Bolen. And he never forgot it because that’s the most East Germans that any ambassador had addressed in East Germany.
The role of the chief USIA officer in the Embassy is a very important role. Through cultural affairs you don't necessarily tear down the barriers, but you create a climate which makes it more amenable for officials to talk and negotiate with each other, especially when there are cultural guests in the country. And you don't get nasty with each other at cultural events. You talk about the community and even identity of interests. And in that respect I think USIA plays a leading role. As one ambassador said to me at the end of my tour, “Your programs were the cutting edge of U.S. policy in our country.” And those are words that I'm always pleased to recall.
Association for Diplomatic Studies and Training

Robert Lochner, Director Radio in the American Sector (RIAS), Berlin, 1961-1968
U.S. diplomat Robert Lochner, seen here, recalled the way he reacted to the building of the Wall in the early hours of its construction in 1961.

I was alerted at one minute past midnight that the East Berlin radio had started to announce that communications within the city were cut. Within fifteen minutes I was down at the station as were all of my colleagues and staff.
All during the night, RIAS was the only station on live all night long at that time. Most German radio stations didn’t carry the news of the Wall until their first live news in the morning at 6 a.m. We carried live news every 15 minutes in the hope that it might still help some people escape.
Three times during the night I went over to East Berlin and because we didn’t know what reception we would get, I hid a tape recorder under a coat. I went and simply drove around and recorded on tape what was going on, reported from the Eastern side and it was broadcast.
The Wall started with work crews tearing up the street and laying rows of barbed wire. Beginning midnight it turned out that the cutting of the city in half was so effective that they started breaking up the streets simultaneously at all the points where later the Wall was constructed.
Association for Diplomatic Studies and Training
Robert Lochner, Director Radio in the American Sector (RIAS), Berlin, 1961-1968
U.S. diplomat Robert Lochner, pictured here, recollected that in his travels around Berlin the morning the Wall went up in 1961, he witnessed many poignant scenes.

As I was standing there observing the scene, a pitiful old woman timidly walked up to one of the guards; they were standing about three steps up, and asked when was the next train due for West Berlin. I will never forget the sneering tone in which the guy answered: “That is all over – you are all sitting in a mousetrap now.”
Association for Diplomatic Studies and Training
Richard C. Barkley, Ambassador, German Democratic Republic, 1988-1990

National unity for Germany stimulated invigorated participation in the European Union, its flag pictured here. U.S. Ambassador Richard Barkley, East Berlin, offered his comments on Germany’s position in the European Union.

Kohl for a long period of time had tried to anchor Germany into the European Union. Of course at that time the European community was a way to make sure there was no going it alone. So for a long time, West Germany had this double policy of trying to alleviate some of the pressures in inter German relations but at the same time anchoring that Germany into a broader European concept. It is something that they continue to do to this day.
Association for Diplomatic Studies and Training
Martha Mautner, Intelligence and Research, Berlin Task Force, 1950-1958
As East Berliners built the Wall dividing their city in August 1961, seen in the photo here, U.S. intelligence officer Martha Mautner remembered her apprehension at the time.

We had lots of indications that something was coming.
Nobody really expected an attempt, to quote Ulbricht, “to put a Chinese wall down the center of the city.” He said that two months before the Wall went up. He, after all, wanted the whole city.
Nobody, and that includes the German government and every other government, ever really penetrated the top hierarchy of the East German regime. A lot of people thought they had contacts there, but I have yet to discover anybody who had a real inside link. Only the Soviets knew what Ulbricht and the others were up to, and even they, I am sure, didn’t know everything.
Association for Diplomatic Studies and Training
Yale Richmond, Cultural Affairs Officer, West Germany, 1951-1952

General Lucius Clay, pictured here, was the Military Governor of the American Zone from 1947-1949. He was an American hero for Berliners during the 1948 Air Lift that U.S. diplomat Yale Richmond recalled in this account.

The Air Lift was only about three years after the end of the war. The Germans were apprehensive. Berlin was always a flashpoint and there was always the fear that something could happen at one of those checkpoints. If somebody shot a few rounds of fire, you might have started World War III. But the Germans were very apprehensive about that. Most of them thought that you could never save Berlin through an airlift. I remember talking to a German who had been in the Luftwaffe during the war and he said, “You’ll never be able to supply the city of Berlin by air.” But we did it. We and the British and the French to a lesser extent.
Association for Diplomatic Studies and Training

Bruce Flatin, Public Safety Section, Berlin, 1964-1969
This 1961 photo of refugees from East Germany illustrates U.S. diplomat Bruce Flatin’s comments on the loss of skilled professionals affecting the East German economy.

They were losing huge numbers of East Germans. It was like a hemorrhage. They were losing very valuable people – doctors, engineers and young people. They’d have been bled dry of their most useful population.
